docs.What it does:
Checks for comparisons where one side of the relation is
either the minimum or maximum value for its type and warns if it involves a
case that is always true or always false. Only integer and boolean types are
checked.
docs.Why is this bad:
An expression like `min <= x` may misleadingly imply
that it is possible for `x` to be less than the minimum. Expressions like
`max < x` are probably mistakes.
docs.Known problems:
For `usize` the size of the current compile target will
be assumed (e.g., 64 bits on 64 bit systems). This means code that uses such
a comparison to detect target pointer width will trigger this lint. One can
use `mem::sizeof` and compare its value or conditional compilation
attributes
like `#[cfg(target_pointer_width = "64")] ..` instead.

docs.What it does: Checks for `foo = bar; bar = foo` sequences.
docs.Why is this bad: This looks like a failed attempt to swap.

docs.What it does:
Checks for floating point literals that approximate
constants which are defined in
[`std::f32::consts`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/f32/consts/#constants)
or
[`std::f64::consts`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/f64/consts/#constants),
respectively, suggesting to use the predefined constant.
docs.Why is this bad:
Usually, the definition in the standard library is more
precise than what people come up with. If you find that your definition is
actually more precise, please [file a Rust
issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues).

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `as` conversions.
docs.Why is this bad:
`as` conversions will perform many kinds of
conversions, including silently lossy conversions and dangerous coercions.
There are cases when it makes sense to use `as`, so the lint is
Allow by default.

docs.What it does: Checks for `assert!(true)` and `assert!(false)` calls.
docs.Why is this bad:
Will be optimized out by the compiler or should probably be replaced by a
panic!() or unreachable!()

docs.What it does:
Checks for `a = a op b` or `a = b commutative_op a`
patterns.
docs.Why is this bad: These can be written as the shorter `a op= b`.
docs.Known problems:
While forbidden by the spec, `OpAssign` traits may have
implementations that differ from the regular `Op` impl.

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
This lint is too subjective, not having a good reason for being in clippy.
Additionally, compound assignment operators may be overloaded separately from their non-assigning
counterparts, so this lint may suggest a change in behavior or the code may not compile.

docs.What it does:
Checks for incompatible bit masks in comparisons.

The formula for detecting if an expression of the type `_ <bit_op> m
<cmp_op> c` (where `<bit_op>` is one of {`&`, `|`} and `<cmp_op>` is one of
{`!=`, `>=`, `>`, `!=`, `>=`, `>`}) can be determined from the following
table:

|Comparison  |Bit Op|Example     |is always|Formula               |
|------------|------|------------|---------|----------------------|
|`==` or `!=`| `&`  |`x & 2 == 3`|`false`  |`c & m != c`          |
|`<`  or `>=`| `&`  |`x & 2 < 3` |`true`   |`m < c`               |
|`>`  or `<=`| `&`  |`x & 1 > 1` |`false`  |`m <= c`              |
|`==` or `!=`| `|`  |`x | 1 == 0`|`false`  |`c | m != c`          |
|`<`  or `>=`| `|`  |`x | 1 < 1` |`false`  |`m >= c`              |
|`<=` or `>` | `|`  |`x | 1 > 0` |`true`   |`m > c`               |
docs.Why is this bad:
If the bits that the comparison cares about are always
set to zero or one by the bit mask, the comparison is constant `true` or
`false` (depending on mask, compared value, and operators).

So the code is actively misleading, and the only reason someone would write
this intentionally is to win an underhanded Rust contest or create a
test-case for this lint.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of blacklisted names for variables, such
as `foo`.
docs.Why is this bad:
These names are usually placeholder names and should be
avoided.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `blacklisted-names: Vec<String>`: The list of blacklisted names to lint about (defaults to `["foo", "bar", "baz", "quux"] `).

docs.What it does:
Checks for `if` conditions that use blocks to contain an
expression.
docs.Why is this bad:
It isn't really Rust style, same as using parentheses
to contain expressions.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `if` conditions that use blocks containing
statements, or conditions that use closures with blocks.
docs.Why is this bad: Using blocks in the condition makes it hard to read.

docs.What it does:
Checks for expressions of the form `x == true`,
`x != true` and order comparisons such as `x < true` (or vice versa) and
suggest using the variable directly.
docs.Why is this bad: Unnecessary code.
docs.Example:
```rust,ignore
if x == true {} // could be `if x { }`
```

docs.What it does:
Checks if `const` items which is interior mutable (e.g.,
contains a `Cell`, `Mutex`, `AtomicXxxx`, etc.) has been borrowed directly.
docs.Why is this bad:
Consts are copied everywhere they are referenced, i.e.,
every time you refer to the const a fresh instance of the `Cell` or `Mutex`
or `AtomicXxxx` will be created, which defeats the whole purpose of using
these types in the first place.

The `const` value should be stored inside a `static` item.

docs.What it does: Checks for use of `&Box<T>` anywhere in the code.
docs.Why is this bad:
Any `&Box<T>` can also be a `&T`, which is more
general.
docs.Example:
```rust,ignore
fn foo(bar: &Box<T>) { ... }
```

Better:

```rust,ignore
fn foo(bar: &T) { ... }
```

docs.What it does: Checks for use of `Box<Vec<_>>` anywhere in the code.
docs.Why is this bad:
`Vec` already keeps its contents in a separate area on
the heap. So if you `Box` it, you just add another level of indirection
without any benefit whatsoever.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `Box<T>` where an unboxed `T` would
work fine.
docs.Why is this bad:
This is an unnecessary allocation, and bad for
performance. It is only necessary to allocate if you wish to move the box
into something.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `too-large-for-stack: u64`: The maximum size of objects (in bytes) that will be linted. Larger objects are ok on the heap (defaults to `200 `).

docs.What it does: Warns if a generic shadows a built-in type.
docs.Why is this bad: This gives surprising type errors.

docs.What it does:
Checks to see if all common metadata is defined in
`Cargo.toml`. See: https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/api-guidelines/documentation.html#cargotoml-includes-all-common-metadata-c-metadata
docs.Why is this bad:
It will be more difficult for users to discover the
purpose of the crate, and key information related to it.
docs.Example:
```toml
# This `Cargo.toml` is missing an authors field:
[package]
name = "clippy"
version = "0.0.212"
description = "A bunch of helpful lints to avoid common pitfalls in Rust"
repository = "https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy"
readme = "README.md"
license = "MIT OR Apache-2.0"
keywords = ["clippy", "lint", "plugin"]
categories = ["development-tools", "development-tools::cargo-plugins"]
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for casts between numerical types that may
be replaced by safe conversion functions.
docs.Why is this bad:
Rust's `as` keyword will perform many kinds of
conversions, including silently lossy conversions. Conversion functions such
as `i32::from` will only perform lossless conversions. Using the conversion
functions prevents conversions from turning into silent lossy conversions if
the types of the input expressions ever change, and make it easier for
people reading the code to know that the conversion is lossless.

docs.What it does:
Checks for casts between numerical types that may
truncate large values. This is expected behavior, so the cast is `Allow` by
default.
docs.Why is this bad:
In some problem domains, it is good practice to avoid
truncation. This lint can be activated to help assess where additional
checks could be beneficial.

docs.What it does:
Checks for casts from an unsigned type to a signed type of
the same size. Performing such a cast is a 'no-op' for the compiler,
i.e., nothing is changed at the bit level, and the binary representation of
the value is reinterpreted. This can cause wrapping if the value is too big
for the target signed type. However, the cast works as defined, so this lint
is `Allow` by default.
docs.Why is this bad:
While such a cast is not bad in itself, the results can
be surprising when this is not the intended behavior, as demonstrated by the
example below.
docs.Example:
```rust
std::u32::MAX as i32; // will yield a value of `-1`
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for casts from any numerical to a float type where
the receiving type cannot store all values from the original type without
rounding errors. This possible rounding is to be expected, so this lint is
`Allow` by default.

Basically, this warns on casting any integer with 32 or more bits to `f32`
or any 64-bit integer to `f64`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It's not bad at all. But in some applications it can be
helpful to know where precision loss can take place. This lint can help find
those places in the code.

docs.What it does:
Checks for casts from a less-strictly-aligned pointer to a
more-strictly-aligned pointer
docs.Why is this bad:
Dereferencing the resulting pointer may be undefined
behavior.
docs.Known problems:
Using `std::ptr::read_unaligned` and `std::ptr::write_unaligned` or similar
on the resulting pointer is fine.

docs.What it does: Checks for casts of `&T` to `&mut T` anywhere in the code.
docs.Why is this bad:
It’s basically guaranteed to be undefined behaviour.
`UnsafeCell` is the only way to obtain aliasable data that is considered
mutable.

docs.What it does:
Checks for casts from a signed to an unsigned numerical
type. In this case, negative values wrap around to large positive values,
which can be quite surprising in practice. However, as the cast works as
defined, this lint is `Allow` by default.
docs.Why is this bad:
Possibly surprising results. You can activate this lint
as a one-time check to see where numerical wrapping can arise.

docs.What it does:
Checks for expressions where a character literal is cast
to `u8` and suggests using a byte literal instead.
docs.Why is this bad:
In general, casting values to smaller types is
error-prone and should be avoided where possible. In the particular case of
converting a character literal to u8, it is easy to avoid by just using a
byte literal instead. As an added bonus, `b'a'` is even slightly shorter
than `'a' as u8`.
docs.Example:
```rust,ignore
'x' as u8
```

A better version, using the byte literal:

```rust,ignore
b'x'
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `.chars().last()` or
`.chars().next_back()` on a `str` to check if it ends with a given char.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as
`_.ends_with(_)`.
docs.Example:
```ignore
name.chars().last() == Some('_') || name.chars().next_back() == Some('-')
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `.chars().next()` on a `str` to check
if it starts with a given char.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as
`_.starts_with(_)`.

docs.What it does: Checks for explicit bounds checking when casting.
docs.Why is this bad: Reduces the readability of statements & is error prone.
docs.Example:
```rust
foo <= i32::max_value() as u32
```

Could be written:

```rust
i32::try_from(foo).is_ok()
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `.clone()` on an `&&T`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Cloning an `&&T` copies the inner `&T`, instead of
cloning the underlying `T`.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `.clone()` on a `Copy` type.
docs.Why is this bad:
The only reason `Copy` types implement `Clone` is for
generics, not for using the `clone` method on a concrete type.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `.clone()` on a ref-counted pointer,
(`Rc`, `Arc`, `rc::Weak`, or `sync::Weak`), and suggests calling Clone via unified
function syntax instead (e.g., `Rc::clone(foo)`).
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling '.clone()' on an Rc, Arc, or Weak
can obscure the fact that only the pointer is being cloned, not the underlying
data.

docs.What it does: Checks for comparisons to NaN.
docs.Why is this bad:
NaN does not compare meaningfully to anything – not
even itself – so those comparisons are simply wrong.

docs.What it does: This lint checks for equality comparisons with `ptr::null`
docs.Why is this bad:
It's easier and more readable to use the inherent
`.is_null()`
method instead

docs.What it does:
Checks for conversions to owned values just for the sake
of a comparison.
docs.Why is this bad:
The comparison can operate on a reference, so creating
an owned value effectively throws it away directly afterwards, which is
needlessly consuming code and heap space.
docs.Example:
```rust
if x.to_owned() == y {}
```
Could be written as
```rust
if x == y {}
```

docs.What it does: Checks for methods with high cognitive complexity.
docs.Why is this bad:
Methods of high cognitive complexity tend to be hard to
both read and maintain. Also LLVM will tend to optimize small methods better.
docs.Known problems:
Sometimes it's hard to find a way to reduce the
complexity.
docs.Example: No. You'll see it when you get the warning.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `cognitive-complexity-threshold: u64`: The maximum cognitive complexity a function can have (defaults to `25 `).

docs.What it does:
Checks for nested `if` statements which can be collapsed
by `&&`-combining their conditions and for `else { if ... }` expressions
that
can be collapsed to `else if ...`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Each `if`-statement adds one level of nesting, which
makes code look more complex than it really is.

docs.What it does:
Checks comparison chains written with `if` that can be
rewritten with `match` and `cmp`.
docs.Why is this bad:
`if` is not guaranteed to be exhaustive and conditionals can get
repetitive

docs.What it does:
Checks for types that implement `Copy` as well as
`Iterator`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Implicit copies can be confusing when working with
iterator combinators.

docs.What it does: Checks for transmutes between a type `T` and `*T`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It's easy to mistakenly transmute between a type and a
pointer to that type.
docs.Example:
```rust,ignore
core::intrinsics::transmute(t) // where the result type is the same as
                               // `*t` or `&t`'s
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of dbg!() macro.
docs.Why is this bad:
`dbg!` macro is intended as a debugging tool. It
should not be in version control.

docs.What it does:
Checks for function/method calls with a mutable
parameter in `debug_assert!`, `debug_assert_eq!` and `debug_assert_ne!` macros.
docs.Why is this bad:
In release builds `debug_assert!` macros are optimized out by the
compiler.
Therefore mutating something in a `debug_assert!` macro results in different behaviour
between a release and debug build.

docs.What it does: Warns if there is a better representation for a numeric literal.
docs.Why is this bad:
Especially for big powers of 2 a hexadecimal representation is more
readable than a decimal representation.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `literal-representation-threshold: u64`: The lower bound for linting decimal literals (defaults to `16384 `).

docs.What it does:
Checks for declaration of `const` items which is interior
mutable (e.g., contains a `Cell`, `Mutex`, `AtomicXxxx`, etc.).
docs.Why is this bad:
Consts are copied everywhere they are referenced, i.e.,
every time you refer to the const a fresh instance of the `Cell` or `Mutex`
or `AtomicXxxx` will be created, which defeats the whole purpose of using
these types in the first place.

The `const` should better be replaced by a `static` item if a global
variable is wanted, or replaced by a `const fn` if a constructor is wanted.
docs.Known problems:
A "non-constant" const item is a legacy way to supply an
initialized value to downstream `static` items (e.g., the
`std::sync::ONCE_INIT` constant). In this case the use of `const` is legit,
and this lint should be suppressed.

docs.What it does: Checks for literal calls to `Default::default()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It's more clear to the reader to use the name of the type whose default is
being gotten than the generic `Default`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `#[cfg_attr(rustfmt, rustfmt_skip)]` and suggests to replace it
with `#[rustfmt::skip]`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Since tool_attributes ([rust-lang/rust#44690](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/44690))
are stable now, they should be used instead of the old `cfg_attr(rustfmt)` attributes.
docs.Known problems:
This lint doesn't detect crate level inner attributes, because they get
processed before the PreExpansionPass lints get executed. See
[#3123](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/pull/3123#issuecomment-422321765)
docs.Example:
Bad:
```rust
#[cfg_attr(rustfmt, rustfmt_skip)]
fn main() { }
```

Good:
```rust
#[rustfmt::skip]
fn main() { }
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for `#[deprecated]` annotations with a `since`
field that is not a valid semantic version.
docs.Why is this bad:
For checking the version of the deprecation, it must be
a valid semver. Failing that, the contained information is useless.
docs.Example:
```rust
#[deprecated(since = "forever")]
fn something_else() { /* ... */ }
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `*&` and `*&mut` in expressions.
docs.Why is this bad:
Immediately dereferencing a reference is no-op and
makes the code less clear.
docs.Known problems:
Multiple dereference/addrof pairs are not handled so
the suggested fix for `x = **&&y` is `x = *&y`, which is still incorrect.

docs.What it does:
Checks for deriving `Hash` but implementing `PartialEq`
explicitly or vice versa.
docs.Why is this bad:
The implementation of these traits must agree (for
example for use with `HashMap`) so it’s probably a bad idea to use a
default-generated `Hash` implementation with an explicitly defined
`PartialEq`. In particular, the following must hold for any type:

```text
k1 == k2 ⇒ hash(k1) == hash(k2)
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for diverging calls that are not match arms or
statements.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is often confusing to read. In addition, the
sub-expression evaluation order for Rust is not well documented.
docs.Known problems:
Someone might want to use `some_bool || panic!()` as a
shorthand.

docs.What it does:
Checks for the presence of `_`, `::` or camel-case words
outside ticks in documentation.
docs.Why is this bad:
*Rustdoc* supports markdown formatting, `_`, `::` and
camel-case probably indicates some code which should be included between
ticks. `_` can also be used for emphasis in markdown, this lint tries to
consider that.
docs.Known problems:
Lots of bad docs won’t be fixed, what the lint checks
for is limited, and there are still false positives.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `doc-valid-idents: Vec<String>`: The list of words this lint should not consider as identifiers needing ticks (defaults to `[
        "KiB", "MiB", "GiB", "TiB", "PiB", "EiB",
        "DirectX",
        "ECMAScript",
        "GPLv2", "GPLv3",
        "GitHub", "GitLab",
        "IPv4", "IPv6",
        "JavaScript",
        "NaN", "NaNs",
        "OAuth",
        "OpenGL", "OpenSSH", "OpenSSL", "OpenStreetMap",
        "TrueType",
        "iOS", "macOS",
        "TeX", "LaTeX", "BibTeX", "BibLaTeX",
        "MinGW",
        "CamelCase",
    ] `).

docs.What it does: Checks for double comparisons that could be simplified to a single expression.
docs.Why is this bad: Readability.
docs.Example:
```rust
if x == y || x < y {}
```

Could be written as:

```rust
if x <= y {}
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for a [`#[must_use]`] attribute without
further information on functions and methods that return a type already
marked as `#[must_use]`.

[`#[must_use]`]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/attributes/diagnostics.html#the-must_use-attribute
docs.Why is this bad:
The attribute isn't needed. Not using the result
will already be reported. Alternatively, one can add some text to the
attribute to improve the lint message.

docs.What it does: Detects expressions of the form `--x`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It can mislead C/C++ programmers to think `x` was
decremented.

docs.What it does: Checks for unnecessary double parentheses.
docs.Why is this bad:
This makes code harder to read and might indicate a
mistake.

docs.What it does: Checks for generics with `std::ops::Drop` as bounds.
docs.Why is this bad:
`Drop` bounds do not really accomplish anything.
A type may have compiler-generated drop glue without implementing the
`Drop` trait itself. The `Drop` trait also only has one method,
`Drop::drop`, and that function is by fiat not callable in user code.
So there is really no use case for using `Drop` in trait bounds.

The most likely use case of a drop bound is to distinguish between types
that have destructors and types that don't. Combined with specialization,
a naive coder would write an implementation that assumed a type could be
trivially dropped, then write a specialization for `T: Drop` that actually
calls the destructor. Except that doing so is not correct; String, for
example, doesn't actually implement Drop, but because String contains a
Vec, assuming it can be trivially dropped will leak memory.

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `std::mem::drop` with a value
that derives the Copy trait
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling `std::mem::drop` [does nothing for types that
implement Copy](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.drop.html), since the
value will be copied and moved into the function on invocation.
docs.Example:
```rust
let x: i32 = 42; // i32 implements Copy
std::mem::drop(x) // A copy of x is passed to the function, leaving the
                  // original unaffected
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `std::mem::drop` with a reference
instead of an owned value.
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling `drop` on a reference will only drop the
reference itself, which is a no-op. It will not call the `drop` method (from
the `Drop` trait implementation) on the underlying referenced value, which
is likely what was intended.

docs.What it does:
Checks for function arguments having the similar names
differing by an underscore.
docs.Why is this bad: It affects code readability.

docs.What it does:
Checks for calculation of subsecond microseconds or milliseconds
from other `Duration` methods.
docs.Why is this bad:
It's more concise to call `Duration::subsec_micros()` or
`Duration::subsec_millis()` than to calculate them.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of if expressions with an `else if` branch,
but without a final `else` branch.
docs.Why is this bad: Some coding guidelines require this (e.g., MISRA-C:2004 Rule 14.10).

docs.What it does: Checks for `enum`s with no variants.
docs.Why is this bad:
Enum's with no variants should be replaced with `!`,
the uninhabited type,
or a wrapper around it.

docs.What it does: Checks for empty lines after outer attributes
docs.Why is this bad:
Most likely the attribute was meant to be an inner attribute using a '!'.
If it was meant to be an outer attribute, then the following item
should not be separated by empty lines.
docs.Known problems:
Can cause false positives.

From the clippy side it's difficult to detect empty lines between an attributes and the
following item because empty lines and comments are not part of the AST. The parsing
currently works for basic cases but is not perfect.

docs.What it does: Checks for empty `loop` expressions.
docs.Why is this bad:
Those busy loops burn CPU cycles without doing
anything. Think of the environment and either block on something or at least
make the thread sleep for some microseconds.

docs.What it does:
Checks for C-like enumerations that are
`repr(isize/usize)` and have values that don't fit into an `i32`.
docs.Why is this bad:
This will truncate the variant value on 32 bit
architectures, but works fine on 64 bit.
docs.Example:
```rust
#[repr(usize)]
enum NonPortable {
    X = 0x1_0000_0000,
    Y = 0,
}
```

docs.What it does: Checks for `use Enum::*`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is usually better style to use the prefixed name of
an enumeration variant, rather than importing variants.
docs.Known problems:
Old-style enumerations that prefix the variants are
still around.

docs.What it does:
Detects enumeration variants that are prefixed or suffixed
by the same characters.
docs.Why is this bad:
Enumeration variant names should specify their variant,
not repeat the enumeration name.
docs.Example:
```rust
enum Cake {
    BlackForestCake,
    HummingbirdCake,
    BattenbergCake,
}
```
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `enum-variant-name-threshold: u64`: The minimum number of enum variants for the lints about variant names to trigger (defaults to `3 `).

docs.What it does:
Checks for equal operands to comparison, logical and
bitwise, difference and division binary operators (`==`, `>`, etc., `&&`,
`||`, `&`, `|`, `^`, `-` and `/`).
docs.Why is this bad: This is usually just a typo or a copy and paste error.
docs.Known problems:
False negatives: We had some false positives regarding
calls (notably [racer](https://github.com/phildawes/racer) had one instance
of `x.pop() && x.pop()`), so we removed matching any function or method
calls. We may introduce a whitelist of known pure functions in the future.

docs.What it does: Checks for erasing operations, e.g., `x * 0`.
docs.Why is this bad:
The whole expression can be replaced by zero.
This is most likely not the intended outcome and should probably be
corrected

docs.What it does:
Checks for a read and a write to the same variable where
whether the read occurs before or after the write depends on the evaluation
order of sub-expressions.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is often confusing to read. In addition, the
sub-expression evaluation order for Rust is not well documented.
docs.Known problems:
Code which intentionally depends on the evaluation
order, or which is correct for any evaluation order.

docs.What it does:
Checks for float literals with a precision greater
than that supported by the underlying type
docs.Why is this bad: Rust will truncate the literal silently.

docs.What it does:
`exit()`  terminates the program and doesn't provide a
stack trace.
docs.Why is this bad:
Ideally a program is terminated by finishing
the main function.
docs.Example:
```ignore
std::process::exit(0)
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `.expect(&format!(...))`, `.expect(foo(..))`,
etc., and suggests to use `unwrap_or_else` instead
docs.Why is this bad: The function will always be called.
docs.Known problems:
If the function has side-effects, not calling it will
change the semantics of the program, but you shouldn't rely on that anyway.
docs.Example:
```rust
foo.expect(&format!("Err {}: {}", err_code, err_msg));
```
or
```rust
foo.expect(format!("Err {}: {}", err_code, err_msg).as_str());
```
this can instead be written:
```rust
foo.unwrap_or_else(|| panic!("Err {}: {}", err_code, err_msg));
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for explicit `Clone` implementations for `Copy`
types.
docs.Why is this bad:
To avoid surprising behaviour, these traits should
agree and the behaviour of `Copy` cannot be overridden. In almost all
situations a `Copy` type should have a `Clone` implementation that does
nothing more than copy the object, which is what `#[derive(Copy, Clone)]`
gets you.
docs.Known problems: Bounds of generic types are sometimes wrong: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/26925

docs.What it does:
Checks `for` loops over slices with an explicit counter
and suggests the use of `.enumerate()`.
docs.Why is it bad:
Using `.enumerate()` makes the intent more clear,
declutters the code and may be faster in some instances.

docs.What it does:
Checks for loops on `y.into_iter()` where `y` will do, and
suggests the latter.
docs.Why is this bad: Readability.

docs.What it does:
Checks for loops on `x.iter()` where `&x` will do, and
suggests the latter.
docs.Why is this bad: Readability.
docs.Known problems:
False negatives. We currently only warn on some known
types.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `write!()` / `writeln()!` which can be
replaced with `(e)print!()` / `(e)println!()`
docs.Why is this bad: Using `(e)println! is clearer and more concise

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
This used to check for `Vec::extend`, which was slower than
`Vec::extend_from_slice`. Thanks to specialization, this is no longer true.

docs.What it does:
Checks for lifetimes in generics that are never used
anywhere else.
docs.Why is this bad:
The additional lifetimes make the code look more
complicated, while there is nothing out of the ordinary going on. Removing
them leads to more readable code.

docs.What it does: Checks for impls of `From<..>` that contain `panic!()` or `unwrap()`
docs.Why is this bad: `TryFrom` should be used if there's a possibility of failure.

docs.What it does: Checks for `FileType::is_file()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
When people testing a file type with `FileType::is_file`
they are testing whether a path is something they can get bytes from. But
`is_file` doesn't cover special file types in unix-like systems, and doesn't cover
symlink in windows. Using `!FileType::is_dir()` is a better way to that intention.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `_.filter(_).map(_)`,
`_.filter(_).flat_map(_)`, `_.filter_map(_).flat_map(_)` and similar.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as a
single method call.
docs.Known problems:
Often requires a condition + Option/Iterator creation
inside the closure.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.filter_map(_).next()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as a
single method call.
docs.Example:
```rust
 (0..3).filter_map(|x| if x == 2 { Some(x) } else { None }).next();
```
Can be written as

```rust
 (0..3).find_map(|x| if x == 2 { Some(x) } else { None });
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.filter(_).next()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as
`_.find(_)`.
docs.Example:
```rust
vec.iter().filter(|x| **x == 0).next();
```
Could be written as
```rust
vec.iter().find(|x| **x == 0);
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.find(_).map(_)`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as a
single method call.
docs.Known problems:
Often requires a condition + Option/Iterator creation
inside the closure.
docs.Example:
```rust
 (0..3).find(|x| *x == 2).map(|x| x * 2);
```
Can be written as
```rust
 (0..3).find_map(|x| if x == 2 { Some(x * 2) } else { None });
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `flat_map(|x| x)`.
docs.Why is this bad: Readability, this can be written more concisely by using `flatten`.
docs.Example:
```rust
iter.flat_map(|x| x);
```
Can be written as
```rust
iter.flatten();
```

docs.What it does: Checks for float arithmetic.
docs.Why is this bad:
For some embedded systems or kernel development, it
can be useful to rule out floating-point numbers.

docs.What it does:
Checks for (in-)equality comparisons on floating-point
values (apart from zero), except in functions called `*eq*` (which probably
implement equality for a type involving floats).
docs.Why is this bad:
Floating point calculations are usually imprecise, so
asking if two values are *exactly* equal is asking for trouble. For a good
guide on what to do, see [the floating point
guide](http://www.floating-point-gui.de/errors/comparison).

docs.What it does:
Checks for (in-)equality comparisons on floating-point
value and constant, except in functions called `*eq*` (which probably
implement equality for a type involving floats).
docs.Why is this bad:
Floating point calculations are usually imprecise, so
asking if two values are *exactly* equal is asking for trouble. For a good
guide on what to do, see [the floating point
guide](http://www.floating-point-gui.de/errors/comparison).

docs.What it does: Checks for casts of function pointers to something other than usize
docs.Why is this bad:
Casting a function pointer to anything other than usize/isize is not portable across
architectures, because you end up losing bits if the target type is too small or end up with a
bunch of extra bits that waste space and add more instructions to the final binary than
strictly necessary for the problem

Casting to isize also doesn't make sense since there are no signed addresses.

docs.What it does:
Checks for casts of a function pointer to a numeric type not wide enough to
store address.
docs.Why is this bad:
Such a cast discards some bits of the function's address. If this is intended, it would be more
clearly expressed by casting to usize first, then casting the usize to the intended type (with
a comment) to perform the truncation.

docs.What it does:
Checks for iterating a map (`HashMap` or `BTreeMap`) and
ignoring either the keys or values.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability. There are `keys` and `values` methods that
can be used to express that don't need the values or keys.

docs.What it does: Checks for `for` loops over `Option` values.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability. This is more clearly expressed as an `if
let`.

docs.What it does: Checks for `for` loops over `Result` values.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability. This is more clearly expressed as an `if
let`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `std::mem::forget` with a value that
derives the Copy trait
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling `std::mem::forget` [does nothing for types that
implement Copy](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.drop.html) since the
value will be copied and moved into the function on invocation.

An alternative, but also valid, explanation is that Copy types do not
implement
the Drop trait, which means they have no destructors. Without a destructor,
there
is nothing for `std::mem::forget` to ignore.
docs.Example:
```rust
let x: i32 = 42; // i32 implements Copy
std::mem::forget(x) // A copy of x is passed to the function, leaving the
                    // original unaffected
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `std::mem::forget` with a reference
instead of an owned value.
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling `forget` on a reference will only forget the
reference itself, which is a no-op. It will not forget the underlying
referenced
value, which is likely what was intended.
docs.Example:
```rust
let x = Box::new(1);
std::mem::forget(&x) // Should have been forget(x), x will still be dropped
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for using `x.get(x.len() - 1)` instead of
`x.last()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Using `x.last()` is easier to read and has the same
result.

Note that using `x[x.len() - 1]` is semantically different from
`x.last()`.  Indexing into the array will panic on out-of-bounds
accesses, while `x.get()` and `x.last()` will return `None`.

There is another lint (get_unwrap) that covers the case of using
`x.get(index).unwrap()` instead of `x[index]`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for use of `.get().unwrap()` (or
`.get_mut().unwrap`) on a standard library type which implements `Index`
docs.Why is this bad:
Using the Index trait (`[]`) is more clear and more
concise.
docs.Known problems:
Not a replacement for error handling: Using either
`.unwrap()` or the Index trait (`[]`) carries the risk of causing a `panic`
if the value being accessed is `None`. If the use of `.get().unwrap()` is a
temporary placeholder for dealing with the `Option` type, then this does
not mitigate the need for error handling. If there is a chance that `.get()`
will be `None` in your program, then it is advisable that the `None` case
is handled in a future refactor instead of using `.unwrap()` or the Index
trait.

docs.What it does: Checks for always-identical `Into`/`From`/`IntoIter` conversions.
docs.Why is this bad: Redundant code.

docs.What it does: Checks for identity operations, e.g., `x + 0`.
docs.Why is this bad:
This code can be removed without changing the
meaning. So it just obscures what's going on. Delete it mercilessly.

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
The original rule will only lint for `if let`. After
making it support to lint `match`, naming as `if let` is not suitable for it.
So, this lint is deprecated.

docs.What it does: * Checks for unnecessary `ok()` in if let.
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling `ok()` in if let is unnecessary, instead match
on `Ok(pat)`

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `!` or `!=` in an if condition with an
else branch.
docs.Why is this bad: Negations reduce the readability of statements.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `if/else` with the same body as the *then* part
and the *else* part.
docs.Why is this bad: This is probably a copy & paste error.

docs.What it does: Checks for consecutive `if`s with the same condition.
docs.Why is this bad: This is probably a copy & paste error.

docs.What it does:
Checks for public `impl` or `fn` missing generalization
over different hashers and implicitly defaulting to the default hashing
algorithm (`SipHash`).
docs.Why is this bad:
`HashMap` or `HashSet` with custom hashers cannot be
used with them.
docs.Known problems:
Suggestions for replacing constructors can contain
false-positives. Also applying suggestions can require modification of other
pieces of code, possibly including external crates.

docs.What it does: Checks for missing return statements at the end of a block.
docs.Why is this bad:
Actually omitting the return keyword is idiomatic Rust code. Programmers
coming from other languages might prefer the expressiveness of `return`. It's possible to miss
the last returning statement because the only difference is a missing `;`. Especially in bigger
code with multiple return paths having a `return` keyword makes it easier to find the
corresponding statements.

docs.What it does:
Warns if an integral or floating-point constant is
grouped inconsistently with underscores.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readers may incorrectly interpret inconsistently
grouped digits.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of indexing or slicing. Arrays are special cases, this lint
does report on arrays if we can tell that slicing operations are in bounds and does not
lint on constant `usize` indexing on arrays because that is handled by rustc's `const_err` lint.
docs.Why is this bad:
Indexing and slicing can panic at runtime and there are
safe alternatives.

docs.What it does:
Checks for bit masks in comparisons which can be removed
without changing the outcome. The basic structure can be seen in the
following table:

|Comparison| Bit Op  |Example    |equals |
|----------|---------|-----------|-------|
|`>` / `<=`|`|` / `^`|`x | 2 > 3`|`x > 3`|
|`<` / `>=`|`|` / `^`|`x ^ 1 < 4`|`x < 4`|
docs.Why is this bad:
Not equally evil as [`bad_bit_mask`](#bad_bit_mask),
but still a bit misleading, because the bit mask is ineffective.
docs.Known problems:
False negatives: This lint will only match instances
where we have figured out the math (which is for a power-of-two compared
value). This means things like `x | 1 >= 7` (which would be better written
as `x >= 6`) will not be reported (but bit masks like this are fairly
uncommon).

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `.to_string()` on an `&&T` where
`T` implements `ToString` directly (like `&&str` or `&&String`).
docs.Why is this bad:
This bypasses the specialized implementation of
`ToString` and instead goes through the more expensive string formatting
facilities.

docs.What it does:
Checks for matches being used to destructure a single-variant enum
or tuple struct where a `let` will suffice.
docs.Why is this bad: Just readability – `let` doesn't nest, whereas a `match` does.

docs.What it does: Checks for iteration that is guaranteed to be infinite.
docs.Why is this bad:
While there may be places where this is acceptable
(e.g., in event streams), in most cases this is simply an error.

docs.What it does: Checks for the definition of inherent methods with a signature of `to_string(&self) -> String`.
docs.Why is this bad: This method is also implicitly defined if a type implements the `Display` trait. As the functionality of `Display` is much more versatile, it should be preferred.

docs.What it does: Checks for the definition of inherent methods with a signature of `to_string(&self) -> String` and if the type implementing this method also implements the `Display` trait.
docs.Why is this bad: This method is also implicitly defined if a type implements the `Display` trait. The less versatile inherent method will then shadow the implementation introduced by `Display`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for items annotated with `#[inline(always)]`,
unless the annotated function is empty or simply panics.
docs.Why is this bad:
While there are valid uses of this annotation (and once
you know when to use it, by all means `allow` this lint), it's a common
newbie-mistake to pepper one's code with it.

As a rule of thumb, before slapping `#[inline(always)]` on a function,
measure if that additional function call really affects your runtime profile
sufficiently to make up for the increase in compile time.
docs.Known problems:
False positives, big time. This lint is meant to be
deactivated by everyone doing serious performance work. This means having
done the measurement.
docs.Example:
```ignore
#[inline(always)]
fn not_quite_hot_code(..) { ... }
```

docs.What it does: Checks for `#[inline]` on trait methods without bodies
docs.Why is this bad:
Only implementations of trait methods may be inlined.
The inline attribute is ignored for trait methods without bodies.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `x >= y + 1` or `x - 1 >= y` (and `<=`) in a block
docs.Why is this bad: Readability -- better to use `> y` instead of `>= y + 1`.
docs.Example:
```rust
if x >= y + 1 {}
```

Could be written as:

```rust
if x > y {}
```

docs.What it does: Checks for plain integer arithmetic.
docs.Why is this bad:
This is only checked against overflow in debug builds.
In some applications one wants explicitly checked, wrapping or saturating
arithmetic.

docs.What it does: Checks for division of integers
docs.Why is this bad:
When outside of some very specific algorithms,
integer division is very often a mistake because it discards the
remainder.

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
This lint has been uplifted to rustc and is now called
`array_into_iter`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `into_iter` calls on references which should be replaced by `iter`
or `iter_mut`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability. Calling `into_iter` on a reference will not move out its
content into the resulting iterator, which is confusing. It is better just call `iter` or
`iter_mut` directly.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of invalid atomic
ordering in atomic loads/stores and memory fences.
docs.Why is this bad:
Using an invalid atomic ordering
will cause a panic at run-time.

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
This lint has been superseded by the warn-by-default
`invalid_value` rustc lint.

docs.What it does:
Checks [regex](https://crates.io/crates/regex) creation
(with `Regex::new`,`RegexBuilder::new` or `RegexSet::new`) for correct
regex syntax.
docs.Why is this bad: This will lead to a runtime panic.
docs.Example:
```ignore
Regex::new("|")
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for comparisons where the relation is always either
true or false, but where one side has been upcast so that the comparison is
necessary. Only integer types are checked.
docs.Why is this bad:
An expression like `let x : u8 = ...; (x as u32) > 300`
will mistakenly imply that it is possible for `x` to be outside the range of
`u8`.

docs.What it does: Checks for items declared after some statement in a block.
docs.Why is this bad:
Items live for the entire scope they are declared
in. But statements are processed in order. This might cause confusion as
it's hard to figure out which item is meant in a statement.

docs.What it does:
Checks for the use of `.cloned().collect()` on slice to
create a `Vec`.
docs.Why is this bad: `.to_vec()` is clearer

docs.What it does: Checks for loops on `x.next()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
`next()` returns either `Some(value)` if there was a
value, or `None` otherwise. The insidious thing is that `Option<_>`
implements `IntoIterator`, so that possibly one value will be iterated,
leading to some hard to find bugs. No one will want to write such code
[except to win an Underhanded Rust
Contest](https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/3hb0wm/underhanded_rust_contest/cu5yuhr).

docs.What it does:
Checks for use of `.iter().nth()` (and the related
`.iter_mut().nth()`) on standard library types with O(1) element access.
docs.Why is this bad:
`.get()` and `.get_mut()` are more efficient and more
readable.

docs.What it does: Checks for the use of `iter.nth(0)`.
docs.Why is this bad:
`iter.nth(0)` is unnecessary, and `iter.next()`
is more readable.

docs.What it does: Checks for use of `.skip(x).next()` on iterators.
docs.Why is this bad: `.nth(x)` is cleaner

docs.What it does: Checks for calling `.step_by(0)` on iterators which panics.
docs.Why is this bad:
This very much looks like an oversight. Use `panic!()` instead if you
actually intend to panic.

docs.What it does:
Checks if you have variables whose name consists of just
underscores and digits.
docs.Why is this bad:
It's hard to memorize what a variable means without a
descriptive name.

docs.What it does:
Warns if the digits of an integral or floating-point
constant are grouped into groups that
are too large.
docs.Why is this bad: Negatively impacts readability.

docs.What it does:
Checks for large size differences between variants on
`enum`s.
docs.Why is this bad:
Enum size is bounded by the largest variant. Having a
large variant
can penalize the memory layout of that enum.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `enum-variant-size-threshold: u64`: The maximum size of a enum's variant to avoid box suggestion (defaults to `200 `).

docs.What it does: Checks for local arrays that may be too large.
docs.Why is this bad: Large local arrays may cause stack overflow.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `array-size-threshold: u64`: The maximum allowed size for arrays on the stack (defaults to `512_000 `).

docs.What it does:
Checks for items that implement `.len()` but not
`.is_empty()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is good custom to have both methods, because for
some data structures, asking about the length will be a costly operation,
whereas `.is_empty()` can usually answer in constant time. Also it used to
lead to false positives on the [`len_zero`](#len_zero) lint – currently that
lint will ignore such entities.

docs.What it does:
Checks for getting the length of something via `.len()`
just to compare to zero, and suggests using `.is_empty()` where applicable.
docs.Why is this bad:
Some structures can answer `.is_empty()` much faster
than calculating their length. So it is good to get into the habit of using
`.is_empty()`, and having it is cheap.
Besides, it makes the intent clearer than a manual comparison in some contexts.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `let`-bindings, which are subsequently
returned.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is just extraneous code. Remove it to make your code
more rusty.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `let _ = <expr>`
where expr is #[must_use]
docs.Why is this bad:
It's better to explicitly
handle the value of a #[must_use] expr

docs.What it does: Checks for binding a unit value.
docs.Why is this bad:
A unit value cannot usefully be used anywhere. So
binding one is kind of pointless.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of any `LinkedList`, suggesting to use a
`Vec` or a `VecDeque` (formerly called `RingBuf`).
docs.Why is this bad:
Gankro says:

> The TL;DR of `LinkedList` is that it's built on a massive amount of
pointers and indirection.
> It wastes memory, it has terrible cache locality, and is all-around slow.
`RingBuf`, while
> "only" amortized for push/pop, should be faster in the general case for
almost every possible
> workload, and isn't even amortized at all if you can predict the capacity
you need.
>
> `LinkedList`s are only really good if you're doing a lot of merging or
splitting of lists.
> This is because they can just mangle some pointers instead of actually
copying the data. Even
> if you're doing a lot of insertion in the middle of the list, `RingBuf`
can still be better
> because of how expensive it is to seek to the middle of a `LinkedList`.
docs.Known problems:
False positives – the instances where using a
`LinkedList` makes sense are few and far between, but they can still happen.

docs.What it does:
Checks for boolean expressions that contain terminals that
can be eliminated.
docs.Why is this bad: This is most likely a logic bug.
docs.Example:
```ignore
if a && b || a { ... }
```
The `b` is unnecessary, the expression is equivalent to `if a`.

docs.What it does: Checks for recursion using the entrypoint.
docs.Why is this bad:
Apart from special setups (which we could detect following attributes like #![no_std]),
recursing into main() seems like an unintuitive antipattern we should be able to detect.

docs.What it does:
Checks for for-loops that manually copy items between
slices that could be optimized by having a memcpy.
docs.Why is this bad: It is not as fast as a memcpy.

docs.What it does:
Checks for expressions of the form `a * b + c`
or `c + a * b` where `a`, `b`, `c` are floats and suggests using
`a.mul_add(b, c)` instead.
docs.Why is this bad:
Calculating `a * b + c` may lead to slight
numerical inaccuracies as `a * b` is rounded before being added to
`c`. Depending on the target architecture, `mul_add()` may be more
performant.
docs.Known problems:
This lint can emit semantic incorrect suggestions.
For example, for `a * b * c + d` the suggestion `a * b.mul_add(c, d)`
is emitted, which is equivalent to `a * (b * c + d)`. (#4735)
docs.Example:
```rust
let foo = (a * b) + c;
```

can be written as

```rust
let foo = a.mul_add(b, c);
```

docs.What it does: Checks for `.checked_add/sub(x).unwrap_or(MAX/MIN)`.
docs.Why is this bad: These can be written simply with `saturating_add/sub` methods.

docs.What it does: Checks for manual swapping.
docs.Why is this bad:
The `std::mem::swap` function exposes the intent better
without deinitializing or copying either variable.

docs.What it does:
Checks for too many variables whose name consists of a
single character.
docs.Why is this bad:
It's hard to memorize what a variable means without a
descriptive name.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `single-char-binding-names-threshold: u64`: The maximum number of single char bindings a scope may have (defaults to `5 `).

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `iterator.map(|x| x.clone())` and suggests
`iterator.cloned()` instead
docs.Why is this bad: Readability, this can be written more concisely

docs.What it does:
Checks for uses of `contains_key` + `insert` on `HashMap`
or `BTreeMap`.
docs.Why is this bad: Using `entry` is more efficient.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.map(_).flatten(_)`,
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as a
single method call.

docs.What it does:
Checks for match which is used to add a reference to an
`Option` value.
docs.Why is this bad: Using `as_ref()` or `as_mut()` instead is shorter.

docs.What it does:
Checks for matches where match expression is a `bool`. It
suggests to replace the expression with an `if...else` block.
docs.Why is this bad: It makes the code less readable.

docs.What it does: Checks for overlapping match arms.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is likely to be an error and if not, makes the code
less obvious.

docs.What it does:
Checks for matches where all arms match a reference,
suggesting to remove the reference and deref the matched expression
instead. It also checks for `if let &foo = bar` blocks.
docs.Why is this bad:
It just makes the code less readable. That reference
destructuring adds nothing to the code.
docs.Example:
```rust,ignore
match x {
    &A(ref y) => foo(y),
    &B => bar(),
    _ => frob(&x),
}
```

docs.What it does: Checks for `match` with identical arm bodies.
docs.Why is this bad:
This is probably a copy & paste error. If arm bodies
are the same on purpose, you can factor them
[using `|`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/patterns.html#multiple-patterns).
docs.Known problems:
False positive possible with order dependent `match`
(see issue
[#860](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/issues/860)).
docs.Example:
```rust,ignore
match foo {
    Bar => bar(),
    Quz => quz(),
    Baz => bar(), // <= oops
}
```

This should probably be
```rust,ignore
match foo {
    Bar => bar(),
    Quz => quz(),
    Baz => baz(), // <= fixed
}
```

or if the original code was not a typo:
```rust,ignore
match foo {
    Bar | Baz => bar(), // <= shows the intent better
    Quz => quz(),
}
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for arm which matches all errors with `Err(_)`
and take drastic actions like `panic!`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is generally a bad practice, just like
catching all exceptions in java with `catch(Exception)`

docs.What it does: Checks for iteration that may be infinite.
docs.Why is this bad:
While there may be places where this is acceptable
(e.g., in event streams), in most cases this is simply an error.
docs.Known problems:
The code may have a condition to stop iteration, but
this lint is not clever enough to analyze it.

docs.What it does: Checks for calls of `mem::discriminant()` on a non-enum type.
docs.Why is this bad:
The value of `mem::discriminant()` on non-enum types
is unspecified.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `std::mem::forget(t)` where `t` is
`Drop`.
docs.Why is this bad:
`std::mem::forget(t)` prevents `t` from running its
destructor, possibly causing leaks.
docs.Example:
```rust
mem::forget(Rc::new(55))
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for `mem::replace()` on an `Option` with
`None`.
docs.Why is this bad:
`Option` already has the method `take()` for
taking its current value (Some(..) or None) and replacing it with
`None`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `std::mem::replace` on a value of type
`T` with `T::default()`.
docs.Why is this bad:
`std::mem` module already has the method `take` to
take the current value and replace it with the default value of that type.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `mem::replace(&mut _, mem::uninitialized())`
and `mem::replace(&mut _, mem::zeroed())`.
docs.Why is this bad:
This will lead to undefined behavior even if the
value is overwritten later, because the uninitialized value may be
observed in the case of a panic.

docs.What it does:
Checks for expressions where `std::cmp::min` and `max` are
used to clamp values, but switched so that the result is constant.
docs.Why is this bad:
This is in all probability not the intended outcome. At
the least it hurts readability of the code.
docs.Example:
```ignore
min(0, max(100, x))
```
It will always be equal to `0`. Probably the author meant to clamp the value
between 0 and 100, but has erroneously swapped `min` and `max`.

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
This lint should never have applied to non-pointer types, as transmuting
between non-pointer types of differing alignment is well-defined behavior (it's semantically
equivalent to a memcpy). This lint has thus been refactored into two separate lints:
cast_ptr_alignment and transmute_ptr_to_ptr.

docs.What it does: Checks for `a op= a op b` or `a op= b op a` patterns.
docs.Why is this bad:
Most likely these are bugs where one meant to write `a
op= b`.
docs.Known problems:
Clippy cannot know for sure if `a op= a op b` should have
been `a = a op a op b` or `a = a op b`/`a op= b`. Therefore, it suggests both.
If `a op= a op b` is really the correct behaviour it should be
written as `a = a op a op b` as it's less confusing.

docs.What it does: Suggests the use of `const` in functions and methods where possible.
docs.Why is this bad: Not having the function const prevents callers of the function from being const as well.
docs.Known problems:
Const functions are currently still being worked on, with some features only being available
on nightly. This lint does not consider all edge cases currently and the suggestions may be
incorrect if you are using this lint on stable.

Also, the lint only runs one pass over the code. Consider these two non-const functions:

```rust
fn a() -> i32 {
    0
}
fn b() -> i32 {
    a()
}
```

When running Clippy, the lint will only suggest to make `a` const, because `b` at this time
can't be const as it calls a non-const function. Making `a` const and running Clippy again,
will suggest to make `b` const, too.

docs.What it does:
Warns if there is missing doc for any documentable item
(public or private).
docs.Why is this bad:
Doc is good. *rustc* has a `MISSING_DOCS`
allowed-by-default lint for
public members, but has no way to enforce documentation of private items.
This lint fixes that.

docs.What it does:
Checks the doc comments of publicly visible functions that
return a `Result` type and warns if there is no `# Errors` section.
docs.Why is this bad:
Documenting the type of errors that can be returned from a
function can help callers write code to handle the errors appropriately.

docs.What it does:
it lints if an exported function, method, trait method with default impl,
or trait method impl is not `#[inline]`.
docs.Why is this bad:
In general, it is not. Functions can be inlined across
crates when that's profitable as long as any form of LTO is used. When LTO is disabled,
functions that are not `#[inline]` cannot be inlined across crates. Certain types of crates
might intend for most of the methods in their public API to be able to be inlined across
crates even when LTO is disabled. For these types of crates, enabling this lint might make
sense. It allows the crate to require all exported methods to be `#[inline]` by default, and
then opt out for specific methods where this might not make sense.

docs.What it does:
Checks for the doc comments of publicly visible
unsafe functions and warns if there is no `# Safety` section.
docs.Why is this bad:
Unsafe functions should document their safety
preconditions, so that users can be sure they are using them safely.

docs.What it does: Warns for mistyped suffix in literals
docs.Why is this bad: This is most probably a typo
docs.Known problems:
- Recommends a signed suffix, even though the number might be too big and an unsigned
  suffix is required
- Does not match on `_128` since that is a valid grouping for decimal and octal numbers

docs.What it does:
Warns on hexadecimal literals with mixed-case letter
digits.
docs.Why is this bad: It looks confusing.

docs.What it does:
Checks for modules that have the same name as their
parent module
docs.Why is this bad:
A typical beginner mistake is to have `mod foo;` and
again `mod foo { ..
}` in `foo.rs`.
The expectation is that items inside the inner `mod foo { .. }` are then
available
through `foo::x`, but they are only available through
`foo::foo::x`.
If this is done on purpose, it would be better to choose a more
representative module name.

docs.What it does:
Detects type names that are prefixed or suffixed by the
containing module's name.
docs.Why is this bad: It requires the user to type the module name twice.

docs.What it does: Checks for modulo arithemtic.
docs.Why is this bad:
The results of modulo (%) operation might differ
depending on the language, when negative numbers are involved.
If you interop with different languages it might be beneficial
to double check all places that use modulo arithmetic.

For example, in Rust `17 % -3 = 2`, but in Python `17 % -3 = -1`.

docs.What it does: Checks for getting the remainder of a division by one.
docs.Why is this bad:
The result can only ever be zero. No one will write
such code deliberately, unless trying to win an Underhanded Rust
Contest. Even for that contest, it's probably a bad idea. Use something more
underhanded.

docs.What it does:
Checks to see if multiple versions of a crate are being
used.
docs.Why is this bad:
This bloats the size of targets, and can lead to
confusing error messages when structs or traits are used interchangeably
between different versions of a crate.
docs.Known problems:
Because this can be caused purely by the dependencies
themselves, it's not always possible to fix this issue.
docs.Example:
```toml
# This will pull in both winapi v0.3.4 and v0.2.8, triggering a warning.
[dependencies]
ctrlc = "3.1.0"
ansi_term = "0.11.0"
```

docs.What it does: Checks for multiple inherent implementations of a struct
docs.Why is this bad: Splitting the implementation of a type makes the code harder to navigate.

docs.What it does:
Checks for public functions that have no
[`#[must_use]`] attribute, but return something not already marked
must-use, have no mutable arg and mutate no statics.

[`#[must_use]`]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/attributes/diagnostics.html#the-must_use-attribute
docs.Why is this bad:
Not bad at all, this lint just shows places where
you could add the attribute.
docs.Known problems:
The lint only checks the arguments for mutable
types without looking if they are actually changed. On the other hand,
it also ignores a broad range of potentially interesting side effects,
because we cannot decide whether the programmer intends the function to
be called for the side effect or the result. Expect many false
positives. At least we don't lint if the result type is unit or already
`#[must_use]`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for a [`#[must_use]`] attribute on
unit-returning functions and methods.

[`#[must_use]`]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/attributes/diagnostics.html#the-must_use-attribute
docs.Why is this bad:
Unit values are useless. The attribute is likely
a remnant of a refactoring that removed the return type.

docs.What it does:
This lint checks for functions that take immutable
references and return
mutable ones.
docs.Why is this bad:
This is trivially unsound, as one can create two
mutable references
from the same (immutable!) source. This
[error](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/39465)
actually lead to an interim Rust release 1.15.1.
docs.Known problems:
To be on the conservative side, if there's at least one
mutable reference
with the output lifetime, this lint will not trigger. In practice, this
case is unlikely anyway.

docs.What it does: Checks for instances of `mut mut` references.
docs.Why is this bad:
Multiple `mut`s don't add anything meaningful to the
source. This is either a copy'n'paste error, or it shows a fundamental
misunderstanding of references.

docs.What it does: Checks for loops which have a range bound that is a mutable variable
docs.Why is this bad: One might think that modifying the mutable variable changes the loop bounds

docs.What it does: Checks for sets/maps with mutable key types.
docs.Why is this bad:
All of `HashMap`, `HashSet`, `BTreeMap` and
`BtreeSet` rely on either the hash or the order of keys be unchanging,
so having types with interior mutability is a bad idea.
docs.Known problems:
We don't currently account for `Rc` or `Arc`, so
this may yield false positives.

docs.What it does: Checks for usages of `Mutex<X>` where an atomic will do.
docs.Why is this bad:
Using a mutex just to make access to a plain bool or
reference sequential is shooting flies with cannons.
`std::sync::atomic::AtomicBool` and `std::sync::atomic::AtomicPtr` are leaner and
faster.
docs.Known problems:
This lint cannot detect if the mutex is actually used
for waiting before a critical section.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usages of `Mutex<X>` where `X` is an integral
type.
docs.Why is this bad:
Using a mutex just to make access to a plain integer
sequential is
shooting flies with cannons. `std::sync::atomic::AtomicUsize` is leaner and faster.
docs.Known problems:
This lint cannot detect if the mutex is actually used
for waiting before a critical section.

docs.What it does: Checks for naive byte counts
docs.Why is this bad:
The [`bytecount`](https://crates.io/crates/bytecount)
crate has methods to count your bytes faster, especially for large slices.
docs.Known problems:
If you have predominantly small slices, the
`bytecount::count(..)` method may actually be slower. However, if you can
ensure that less than 2³²-1 matches arise, the `naive_count_32(..)` can be
faster in those cases.
docs.Example:
```rust
&vec.iter().filter(|x| **x == 0u8).count(); // use bytecount::count instead
```

docs.Why is this bad: Redundant code.
docs.Known problems:
Maybe false positives: Sometimes, the two branches are
painstakingly documented (which we, of course, do not detect), so they *may*
have some value. Even then, the documentation can be rewritten to match the
shorter code.

docs.What it does:
Checks for address of operations (`&`) that are going to
be dereferenced immediately by the compiler.
docs.Why is this bad:
Suggests that the receiver of the expression borrows
the expression.

docs.What it does: Checks for useless borrowed references.
docs.Why is this bad:
It is mostly useless and make the code look more
complex than it
actually is.
docs.Example:
```rust
let mut v = Vec::<String>::new();
let _ = v.iter_mut().filter(|&ref a| a.is_empty());
```
This closure takes a reference on something that has been matched as a
reference and
de-referenced.
As such, it could just be |a| a.is_empty()

docs.What it does:
Checks for functions collecting an iterator when collect
is not needed.
docs.Why is this bad:
`collect` causes the allocation of a new data structure,
when this allocation may not be needed.

docs.What it does:
The lint checks for `if`-statements appearing in loops
that contain a `continue` statement in either their main blocks or their
`else`-blocks, when omitting the `else`-block possibly with some
rearrangement of code can make the code easier to understand.
docs.Why is this bad:
Having explicit `else` blocks for `if` statements
containing `continue` in their THEN branch adds unnecessary branching and
nesting to the code. Having an else block containing just `continue` can
also be better written by grouping the statements following the whole `if`
statement within the THEN block and omitting the else block completely.

docs.What it does: Checks for `fn main() { .. }` in doctests
docs.Why is this bad:
The test can be shorter (and likely more readable)
if the `fn main()` is left implicit.

docs.What it does:
Checks for lifetime annotations which can be removed by
relying on lifetime elision.
docs.Why is this bad:
The additional lifetimes make the code look more
complicated, while there is nothing out of the ordinary going on. Removing
them leads to more readable code.
docs.Known problems:
Potential false negatives: we bail out if the function
has a `where` clause where lifetimes are mentioned.

docs.What it does:
Checks for functions taking arguments by value, but not
consuming them in its
body.
docs.Why is this bad:
Taking arguments by reference is more flexible and can
sometimes avoid
unnecessary allocations.
docs.Known problems:
* This lint suggests taking an argument by reference,
however sometimes it is better to let users decide the argument type
(by using `Borrow` trait, for example), depending on how the function is used.

docs.What it does:
Checks for looping over the range of `0..len` of some
collection just to get the values by index.
docs.Why is this bad:
Just iterating the collection itself makes the intent
more clear and is probably faster.

docs.What it does: Checks for return statements at the end of a block.
docs.Why is this bad:
Removing the `return` and semicolon will make the code
more rusty.
docs.Known problems:
If the computation returning the value borrows a local
variable, removing the `return` may run afoul of the borrow checker.

docs.What it does:
Checks for needlessly including a base struct on update
when all fields are changed anyway.
docs.Why is this bad:
This will cost resources (because the base has to be
somewhere), and make the code less readable.

docs.What it does:
Checks for the usage of negated comparison operators on types which only implement
`PartialOrd` (e.g., `f64`).
docs.Why is this bad:
These operators make it easy to forget that the underlying types actually allow not only three
potential Orderings (Less, Equal, Greater) but also a fourth one (Uncomparable). This is
especially easy to miss if the operator based comparison result is negated.

docs.What it does: Checks for multiplication by -1 as a form of negation.
docs.Why is this bad: It's more readable to just negate.
docs.Example:
```ignore
x * -1
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for loops that will always `break`, `return` or
`continue` an outer loop.
docs.Why is this bad:
This loop never loops, all it does is obfuscating the
code.

docs.What it does: Checks for `new` not returning `Self`.
docs.Why is this bad:
As a convention, `new` methods are used to make a new
instance of a type.

docs.What it does:
Checks for types with a `fn new() -> Self` method and no
implementation of
[`Default`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/default/trait.Default.html).

It detects both the case when a manual
[`Default`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/default/trait.Default.html)
implementation is required and also when it can be created with
`#[derive(Default)]`
docs.Why is this bad:
The user might expect to be able to use
[`Default`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/default/trait.Default.html) as the
type can be constructed without arguments.

docs.What it does: Checks for statements which have no effect.
docs.Why is this bad:
Similar to dead code, these statements are actually
executed. However, as they have no effect, all they do is make the code less
readable.

docs.What it does: Checks for non-ASCII characters in string literals.
docs.Why is this bad:
Yeah, we know, the 90's called and wanted their charset
back. Even so, there still are editors and other programs out there that
don't work well with Unicode. So if the code is meant to be used
internationally, on multiple operating systems, or has other portability
requirements, activating this lint could be useful.
docs.Example:
```rust
let x = String::from("€");
```
Could be written as:
```rust
let x = String::from("\u{20ac}");
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for boolean expressions that can be written more
concisely.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability of boolean expressions suffers from
unnecessary duplication.
docs.Known problems:
Ignores short circuiting behavior of `||` and
`&&`. Ignores `|`, `&` and `^`.
docs.Example:
```ignore
if a && true  // should be: if a
if !(a == b)  // should be: if a != b
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for duplicate open options as well as combinations
that make no sense.
docs.Why is this bad:
In the best case, the code will be harder to read than
necessary. I don't know the worst case.

docs.What it does:
Checks for public functions that dereference raw pointer
arguments but are not marked unsafe.
docs.Why is this bad:
The function should probably be marked `unsafe`, since
for an arbitrary raw pointer, there is no way of telling for sure if it is
valid.
docs.Known problems:
* It does not check functions recursively so if the pointer is passed to a
private non-`unsafe` function which does the dereferencing, the lint won't
trigger.
* It only checks for arguments whose type are raw pointers, not raw pointers
got from an argument in some other way (`fn foo(bar: &[*const u8])` or
`some_argument.get_raw_ptr()`).

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `ok().expect(..)`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Because you usually call `expect()` on the `Result`
directly to get a better error message.
docs.Known problems: The error type needs to implement `Debug`
docs.Example:
```ignore
x.ok().expect("why did I do this again?")
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for arguments to `==` which have their address
taken to satisfy a bound
and suggests to dereference the other argument instead
docs.Why is this bad: It is more idiomatic to dereference the other argument.
docs.Example:
```ignore
&x == y
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.and_then(|x| Some(y))`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as
`_.map(|x| y)`.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.as_ref().map(Deref::deref)` or it's aliases (such as String::as_str).
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as a
single method call.
docs.Example:
```rust,ignore
 opt.as_ref().map(String::as_str)
```
Can be written as
```rust,ignore
 opt.as_deref()
```

docs.What it does: Checks for `.expect()` calls on `Option`s.
docs.Why is this bad:
Usually it is better to handle the `None` case. Still,
 for a lot of quick-and-dirty code, `expect` is a good choice, which is why
 this lint is `Allow` by default.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.map_or(None, _)`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as
`_.and_then(_)`.
docs.Known problems: The order of the arguments is not in execution order.
docs.Example:
```ignore
opt.map_or(None, |a| a + 1)
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `option.map(f)` where f is a function
or closure that returns the unit type.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more clearly with
an if let statement

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.map(_).unwrap_or(_)`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as
`_.map_or(_, _)`.
docs.Known problems: The order of the arguments is not in execution order

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `_.map(_).unwrap_or_else(_)`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability, this can be written more concisely as
`_.map_or_else(_, _)`.
docs.Known problems: The order of the arguments is not in execution order.

docs.What it does:
Checks for use of `Option<Option<_>>` in function signatures and type
definitions
docs.Why is this bad:
`Option<_>` represents an optional value. `Option<Option<_>>`
represents an optional optional value which is logically the same thing as an optional
value but has an unneeded extra level of wrapping.

docs.What it does: Checks for `.unwrap()` calls on `Option`s.
docs.Why is this bad:
Usually it is better to handle the `None` case, or to
at least call `.expect(_)` with a more helpful message. Still, for a lot of
quick-and-dirty code, `unwrap` is a good choice, which is why this lint is
`Allow` by default.

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `.or(foo(..))`, `.unwrap_or(foo(..))`,
etc., and suggests to use `or_else`, `unwrap_or_else`, etc., or
`unwrap_or_default` instead.
docs.Why is this bad:
The function will always be called and potentially
allocate an object acting as the default.
docs.Known problems:
If the function has side-effects, not calling it will
change the semantic of the program, but you shouldn't rely on that anyway.
docs.Example:
```rust
foo.unwrap_or(String::new());
```
this can instead be written:
```rust
foo.unwrap_or_else(String::new);
```
or
```rust
foo.unwrap_or_default();
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for out of bounds array indexing with a constant
index.
docs.Why is this bad: This will always panic at runtime.

docs.What it does: Detects classic underflow/overflow checks.
docs.Why is this bad:
Most classic C underflow/overflow checks will fail in
Rust. Users can use functions like `overflowing_*` and `wrapping_*` instead.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `panic!`.
docs.Why is this bad: `panic!` will stop the execution of the executable

docs.What it does: Checks for missing parameters in `panic!`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Contrary to the `format!` family of macros, there are
two forms of `panic!`: if there are no parameters given, the first argument
is not a format string and used literally. So while `format!("{}")` will
fail to compile, `panic!("{}")` will not.

docs.What it does: Checks for calls of `unwrap[_err]()` that will always fail.
docs.Why is this bad: If panicking is desired, an explicit `panic!()` should be used.
docs.Known problems:
This lint only checks `if` conditions not assignments.
So something like `let x: Option<()> = None; x.unwrap();` will not be recognized.

docs.What it does: Checks for manual re-implementations of `PartialEq::ne`.
docs.Why is this bad:
`PartialEq::ne` is required to always return the
negated result of `PartialEq::eq`, which is exactly what the default
implementation does. Therefore, there should never be any need to
re-implement it.

docs.What it does:
* Checks for [push](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/path/struct.PathBuf.html#method.push)
calls on `PathBuf` that can cause overwrites.
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling `push` with a root path at the start can overwrite the
previous defined path.

docs.What it does:
Checks for possible missing comma in an array. It lints if
an array element is a binary operator expression and it lies on two lines.
docs.Why is this bad: This could lead to unexpected results.

docs.What it does:
Checks for operations where precedence may be unclear
and suggests to add parentheses. Currently it catches the following:
* mixed usage of arithmetic and bit shifting/combining operators without
parentheses
* a "negative" numeric literal (which is really a unary `-` followed by a
numeric literal)
  followed by a method call
docs.Why is this bad:
Not everyone knows the precedence of those operators by
heart, so expressions like these may trip others trying to reason about the
code.
docs.Example:
* `1 << 2 + 3` equals 32, while `(1 << 2) + 3` equals 7
* `-1i32.abs()` equals -1, while `(-1i32).abs()` equals 1

docs.What it does: This lint warns about the use of literals as `print!`/`println!` args.
docs.Why is this bad:
Using literals as `println!` args is inefficient
(c.f., https://github.com/matthiaskrgr/rust-str-bench) and unnecessary
(i.e., just put the literal in the format string)
docs.Known problems:
Will also warn with macro calls as arguments that expand to literals
-- e.g., `println!("{}", env!("FOO"))`.
docs.Example:
```rust
println!("{}", "foo");
```
use the literal without formatting:
```rust
println!("foo");
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for printing on *stdout*. The purpose of this lint
is to catch debugging remnants.
docs.Why is this bad:
People often print on *stdout* while debugging an
application and might forget to remove those prints afterward.

docs.What it does:
This lint warns when you use `print!()` with a format
string that
ends in a newline.
docs.Why is this bad:
You should use `println!()` instead, which appends the
newline.
docs.Example:
```rust
print!("Hello {}!\n", name);
```
use println!() instead
```rust
println!("Hello {}!", name);
```

docs.What it does:
This lint warns when you use `println!("")` to
print a newline.
docs.Why is this bad: You should use `println!()`, which is simpler.

docs.What it does:
This lint checks for function arguments of type `&String`
or `&Vec` unless the references are mutable. It will also suggest you
replace `.clone()` calls with the appropriate `.to_owned()`/`to_string()`
calls.
docs.Why is this bad:
Requiring the argument to be of the specific size
makes the function less useful for no benefit; slices in the form of `&[T]`
or `&str` usually suffice and can be obtained from other types, too.
docs.Known problems:
The lint does not follow data. So if you have an
